intro: Quercus calliprinos var. rigida, commonly known as the rigid canyon oak, is a subspecies of the canyon oak native to the southwestern United States. It is a deciduous tree characterized by its thick, leathery leaves that are typically gray-green in color. The tree produces small, acorn-like fruits that are an important food source for various wildlife species. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Its rugged appearance and drought tolerance make it a hardy and ecologically significant plant in its native habitat.
